title: Indigenous Peoples of São Vicente (Pindorama)

maps.text: Different regions were defined in past centuries by non-native people.

common.text:
### The Peopling of Brazil

It is not unusual to talk with people and, when asking them *"Who discovered Brazil?"*, to receive the answer: *"The Portuguese"*. But how could the Portuguese have *"discovered"* it when there were already people here?

Another important issue is the traditional approach to history teaching, which frequently omits the existence of *Pindorama* (the Indigenous name for the Brazilian territory) (<htcite0>; <htcite1>). The conventional narrative only begins discussing this region when it becomes "Brazil".

This text seeks to recover the memory of Indigenous peoples by presenting their familial and social structures. We will also discuss racial mixing and attempt to reassess their Indigenous past (<htcite2>).

#### The First Inhabitants

**Figure 1** shows a map with territorial borders established over centuries, which differ significantly from the lands occupied by hunter-gatherer peoples. These groups moved seasonally, adapting to climate changes (<htcite0>).

The first inhabitants arrived around <htdate0> and remained in the region until <htdate1>. They did not practice agriculture nor use ceramics, living mainly along the coast, where they had abundant marine protein sources. The accumulation of shells and bones formed **sambaquis** (shell mounds) (<htcite1>; <htcite2>; <htcite3>).

Another key detail is their life expectancy, estimated at around 30 years (<htcite4>), which contrasts with European accounts from the early colonial period.

Although they declined with the arrival of the Tupi-Guaraní, there is no evidence they went completely extinct; instead, they integrated with the newcomers (<htcite5>). Some researchers suggest the *Botocudos* may be their descendants (<htcite6>).

#### Tupi-Guarani

By <htdate0>, the Tupi-Guaraní—originating from the continent's interior—reached the coast, displacing earlier groups. Unlike their predecessors, they had ceramics, agriculture, and warfare techniques, using bows and arrows (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

In the 500 years before colonization, these groups were mainly coastal. The Tupi, however, preferred the highlands, where the land was better for farming, only visiting the coast for fishing and rituals (<htcite2>).

It is also important to note the internal conflicts and territorial divisions that emerged with the Tupi-Guaraní migration. An emblematic example is the warfare between the Tupi and Carijós (<htcite3>).

#### The Arrival of Europeans

The European colonization of South America (known as *Abya Yala* by Indigenous peoples) brought profound changes, including a demographic collapse that reduced Indigenous populations by millions (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

Additionally, the Treaty of Tordesillas (**Figura 2**) (<htcite2>) wimposed territorial divisions without Indigenous consent.

Figure 2: Page from the Tratado de Tordesillas mentioning Rui Leme (Biblioteca Nacional de Portugal - BNP, BN MS. 5, n.º 25, F. 6r). ).

Reflection 2: On Land Division

Imagine a scenario where a group of people gathers for a meeting and decides to divide the world among themselves, claiming ownership of everything that has been built over millennia. Would you feel comfortable with the idea of being left with nothing?

We also highlight an aspect in **Figure 1**, based on Dr. Jorge Pimentel Cintra’s research. His analysis of Luiz Teixeira’s <htdate0> map—depicting the hereditary captaincies divided horizontally—cross-references land grants and records from the Torre do Tombo. Using this framework, Dr. Cintra proposes a revised map of the captaincies. In this text, we focus specifically on São Vicente and Santo Amaro (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

prerequisites: Indígenas de Abya Yala (América): Una visión general de cómo ocurrió la migración hasta América.

history.text:
It is impossible to determine individual names when working with sambaquis. Therefore, denying their existence would be much worse. With this, we will present some individuals as "unknown".

Their presence in the Brazilian territory (*Pindorama*) is incontestable, with sambaquis found in different regions (<htcite0>). The mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) collected in Thiago Ferraz da Silva’s research shows that individuals had haplogroups characteristic of the Americas (*Abya Yala*)—A2, B2, C1b, C1c, C1d, and D1—with a rare exception: C4c (<htcite1>).

As for the Y chromosome, the identified haplogroup was Q1b, the most common among Indigenous peoples of South America (*Abya Yala*) (<htcite2>).
The details about this millennia-old individual were presented earlier in this text. We selected mtDNA A2 as an example.
Like their supposed spouse, we are not providing more details beyond what has been stated.
Given the size of the sambaquis and the archaeological data collected, there is no doubt they had children.

As a Brazilian Indigenous woman, few records about her can be found from the 16th century, according to the Gregorian calendar.

We begin the family line with her, respecting the Indigenous matriarchal traditions discussed in the text about the Indigenous peoples of *Abya Yala* (<htcite0>).

She lived in the 16th century, during a historical period marked by the arrival of Europeans on the Brazilian coast, around the year <htdate0>, as shown in her daughter’s testimony during the canonization process of Saint José de Anchieta (<htcite0>).

Her Indigenous origin has been known for centuries, noted in the marriage dispensation of her descendants, Brás Esteves and Maria de Luiz Cunha, in the year <htdate1>, and corroborated by recent genetic testing (<htcite1>; <htcite2>). Nevertheless, we have no indication of how she was known among her Indigenous parents and relatives, and only have the name she received after colonization began.

Without providing any documentation to support his claim, Luiz Gonsaga da Silva Leme referred to her as “Portuguese”. However, that is not the only notable point in his text. When discussing her husband and the couple’s possessions in the 16th century, he mentions part of the São Jorge dos Erasmos sugar mill which, despite the unclear date of its founding, was already facing problems in <htdate2>, as shown in a document preserved in the *Archives Généraux du Royaume* in Brussels, Belgium (<htcite3>; <htcite4>; <htcite5>).
She was mentioned by her daughter in testimony during the process for Saint José de Anchieta
According to her own daughter

Various authors have recorded different spellings of her name. In this text, we adopt the version found in the marriage dispensation of her descendants (<htcite0>).

As with her mother, there is little direct information available about her. The most notable detail is her longevity, mentioned in her testimony during the canonization process of Saint José de Anchieta, in which, in <htdate0>, she declared herself to be over 80 years old (<htcite1>).

She died in <htdate1>, having had seven children (<htcite2>; <htcite3>).
As recorded in her inventory and that of her husband
According to the mother's inventory
According to the mother's inventory
According to the mother's inventory
According to the mother's inventory, through her husband, and indirectly through her own inventory
According to the mother's inventory
According to the mother's inventory

Izabel do Prado had a long life, like her mother, passing away in <htdate0>. After the death of her husband, Pascoal Leite, in <htdate1>, she did not remarry (<htcite0>).

A mistaken publication by Pedro Taques de Almeida Paes Leme attempted to link her husband, Pascoal Leite, to Pascoal Leite Furtado, and several researchers and historians repeated this incorrect information. However, the publication of probate records (inventory), the *De Genere* by João Leite da Silva, and the canonization process of Saint José de Anchieta helped correct the error (<htcite1>; <htcite2>; <htcite3>; <htcite4>).

Izabel do Prado’s probate record (inventory) only mentions male heirs. Therefore, we recommend consulting the work of José Guimarães for a more detailed study of the lineage. For now, we focus solely on Maria Leite, who married Pero Dias (<htcite5>; <htcite6>).
Mentioned in the *De Genere* of her grandson, as well as appearing in her father-in-law’s probate record
According to the *De Genere* of her son (<htcite0>).

Her generation (<htcite0>) is mentioned within her husband’s family. In this text, we only highlight that she was the mother of a *bandeirante* who, despite having Indigenous mtDNA, took actions against his own relatives (<htcite1>; <htcite2>).

source.text: de Vasconcellos, Diogo Luiz de A. P.
Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., Vol. III

history.text: Mentioned in her son's *De Genere* and in her inventory

Helena do Prado is mentioned in her mother’s inventory as the wife of Pero Leme (<htcite0>).

Details about her children are available on her husband's page.

When her son, Domingos Leme da Silva, married on <htdate0>, both she and her husband had already passed away (<htcite1>).
Mentioned in her mother's inventory

exercise_v2.question: Houve habitantes no Brasil (Pindorama) antes da invenção da escrita na Suméria, ou seja, há mais de 6 milênios?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: A datação dos primeiros escritos sumérios ocorrem por volta de 5400 anos, enquanto os creadores de sambaquis vivem no Brasil a aproximadamente 10.000 anos, logo pessoas viviam no país muito antes da escrita surgir na Suméria.
